llm.feedback: Remove every sentence that references spx, mortgage‑backed securities, or equity‑specific data (e.g., “The concentration of the top ten constituents now accounts for 40 % of spx (FAN5RYW6T).”, “The S&P 500 sits at ~6,460…”, “10‑year UST yields are at 4.23% tightening the carry on equities (97MD1FHW8).”, “Core PCE inflation held at 2.6%…”, “The Fed’s dovish tone…”, “If the Fed delivers the expected cut, the S&P 500 would likely break above 6,500…”, “Conversely, a delay…”, “The market’s reaction to the tariff policy…”, “Base case: the S&P 500 will trade between 6,400 and 6,500…”, “Watch next: Fed’s September meeting minutes, the 10‑year yield trajectory, and any tariff policy updates…”, and any other equity‑centric commentary). Also delete the mortgage‑specific portions of the risk discussion (“Key risks to this view include a potential Fed policy reversal driven by a sudden inflation spike…”, “Watching the Fed’s policy statements, the CPI/PCE releases, Treasury auction results, and the monthly mortgage‑originating volume…”) and replace them with a concise, DXY‑centric risk list that cites only Fed minutes, CPI/PCE, debt issuance, and the 2‑yr/10‑yr spread. Keep all sentences that directly tie Fed actions, term‑premium dynamics, and the 2‑yr/10‑yr spread to DXY movement, ensuring each contains an inline citation (e.g., (LF0UUL917), (B1KYJ1GPU), (Z7O1DCHS7)). The final draft should read exclusively about DXY, its causal chain, catalysts, and risk factors, with no mention of spx, mortgage rates, or equity indices.
